Sx1.T1.caption: Table 1: General conversion rules for generating full-sentence answers.
Sx1.T1.table:
Type Rule (Qâ†’â†’\rightarrowA) Question Ans. Converted Ans.
yes/no VB1+NP+VB2/JJ? â€“ â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowâ€œYes,â€+NP+conjug(VB2/JJ,tense(VB1)) or, Did he get hurt? yes Yes, he got hurt.
â€œNo,â€+NP+negate(conjug(VB2/JJ,tense(VB1))) Is she happy? no No, she is not happy.
MD+ NP+VB? â€“ â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowâ€œYes,â€+NP+MD+VB or, Will the boy fall asleep? yes Yes, the boy will fall asleep.
â€œNo,â€+NP+negate(MD)+VB May he cross the road? no No, he may not cross the road.
number â€œHow manyâ€+NP+/is/are+EX?â†’â†’\rightarrowEX+is/are+ans+NP How many pens are there? 2 There are 2 pens.
â€œHow manyâ€+NP1(+MD)+VB(+NP2)? â€“ â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowans(+MD)+VB(+NP2) How many people are walking? 3 3 people are walking.
â€œHow manyâ€+NP1+VB1/MD+NP2+VB2? â€“ â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowNP2+(MD+VB2)/conjug(VB2,tense(VB1))+ans+NP1 How many pens does he have? 4 He has 4 pens.
others WP/WRB/WDT+â€œis/areâ€+NP?â†’â†’\,\to\,NP+â€œis/areâ€+ans. Who are they? students They are students.
WP+NP+VP?â†’â†’\,\to\,ans.+VP What food is on the table? apple Apple is on the table.
WDT+NP+VP(+NP2)?â†’â†’\rightarrowans.(+NP)+VP(+NP2) Which hand is holding it? left Left hand is holding it.
WP/WDT+MD+VB?â†’â†’\rightarrowans.+MD+VB Who would like this? dog Dog would like this.
WP/WDT+MD+NP+VB?â†’â†’\rightarrowNP+MD+VB+ans. What would the man eat? apple The man would eat apple.
WP/WDT+VP(+NP)?â†’â†’\rightarrowans.+VP(+NP) Who threw the ball? pitcher Pitcher threw the ball.
WP/WDT+VB1+NP+VB2? â€“ â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowNP+conjug(VB2,tense(VB1))+ans. What is the man eating? apple The man is eating apple.
references: VQA dataset mainly consists of three categories of questions; yes/no, number, and others. Table 1 summarizes the general conversion rule for generating full-sentence answers for each category, along with examples. Part-of-speech tag notation follows that of PennTree I Tags (?), except NP and VP refer to parse tree instead of than part-of-speech. tense:ğ•â†’ğ•‹â†’ğ•ğ•‹\mathbb{V}\,\to\,\mathbb{T} returns the tense of the input verb, conjug:ğ•Ã—ğ•‹â†’ğ•â†’ğ•ğ•‹ğ•\mathbb{V}\times\mathbb{T}\to\,\mathbb{V} conjugates the input verb to the input tense, where ğ•ğ•\mathbb{V} is a space of verbs of all forms, and ğ•‹ğ•‹\mathbb{T} is a set of tenses such that ğ•‹ğ•‹\mathbb{T}={past, present, future, past perfect, present perfect, future perfect}, except it returns the input as is if the input is of JJ tag. negate:ğ•â†’ğ•â†’ğ•ğ•\mathbb{V}\,\to\,\mathbb{V} negates the input verb of given tense, and replace(A,B) substitutes A by B. Parentheses indicate an optional addition, while A/B indicates an insertion of one of the two sides depending on the question. To briefly illustrate the process, these general conversion rules substitute the question phrase with the answer, and reorder the sentence with appropriate conjugation and negation.

We also generated questions that are category-specific. When an object or a property of a specific category is referred to, we replace it with the category name, preceded by wh-determiner or wh-pronoun, to ask which object or property it belongs to. Our manually pre-defined categories included color, animal, room, food, transportation, and sport. Other rules are mostly reversed process of the conversion rules in Table 1, in which we deliberately mask certain content of the caption, replace it with appropriate question forms, and reorder the sentence.

Sx1.T2.caption: Table 2: General conversion rules for converting captions to questions.
Sx1.T2.table:
Type Rule (Câ†’â†’\rightarrowQ) Caption Question
yes/no NPâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ€œDoes it look likeâ€+NP A man. Does it look like a man?
NP1 + VB (+NP2) â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowconjug(â€œdo/beâ€,tense(VB))+NP1+conjug(VB,present)(+NP2)? A dog jumped. Did a dog jump?
NP1+MD+VB(+NP2)â†’â†’\rightarrowMD+NP1+VB(+NP2)? A boy would hit the ball. Would a boy hit the ball?
EX+â€œis/areâ€+NPâ†’â†’\rightarrowâ€œis/areâ€+EX+NP? There are cats. Are there cats?
same as above except replace(NP1,random NP) or, People are playing baseball. Are cats playing baseball?
replace(VB,random VB) People are playing baseball. Are people making coffee?
number EX+is/are+num+NPâ†’â†’\rightarrowHow many+NP+is/are+EX? There are two cats. How many cats are there?
num+NP+VBâ†’â†’\rightarrowreplace(num,how many) Six cars are parked. How many cars are parked?
others NP1(+MD)+VBâ†’â†’\,\to\,WP(+MD)+VB? or, A boy is running. Who is running?
â†’â†’\rightarrowWP+MD/conjug(â€œdo/beâ€,tense(VB))+NP+â€œdo/doingâ€)? A boy is running. What is a boy doing?
obj/property+VB(+NP)â†’â†’\,\to\,WP/WDT+category+VP(+NP) An apple is shown. What fruit is shown?
NP1+VB(+NP2)+IN+NP3 â€“ â€“
â†’â†’\rightarrowWRB+conjug(â€œdo/beâ€,tense(VB))+NP1+conjug(VB,tense(VB))? Dogs run in a park. Where do dogs run?
references: We also provide an augmented version of the dataset by converting the human-written captions for images into questions and answers. Apart from yes/no questions, the answers to the generated questions are the captions themselves, eliminating the burden for generating reliable answers. Most images in MS COCO come with 5 captions, and we generated distinct question for each caption, whose conversion rule is shown in Table 2.

Sx3.T3.caption: Table 3: Statistics for VQA and two versions of FSVQA dataset. Note that statistics for VQA dataset were computed from the most frequent answers for each question.
Sx3.T3.table:
Dataset split number of avg len number of number of top 1k answers
Q&A pairs answer unique answers unique words coverage(%)

all 986,628 10.33 853,001 69,486 4.83
references: Table 3 shows statistics for original VQA dataset and two versions of FSVQA dataset. Both versions of FSVQA contain much longer answers on average, and the number of unique answers is more than ten times larger in the regular version and about 38 times larger in the augmented version compared to VQA dataset. Augmented version is longer since captions in MS COCO tend to be longer than questions in VQA. The size of vocabularies is also many times larger in both versions. Note that, consistently with the conversion process, only the most frequent answer from 10 answers per question was taken into consideration for VQA datasetâ€™s statistics.

Sx3.T4.caption: Table 4: Number of unique answers for each category.
Sx3.T4.table:
Dataset yes/no number others
VQA 2 817 21,678
FSVQA 98,700 27,119 122,324
FSVQA aug. 485,428 72,970 294,603
references: Table 4 shows the number of unique answers for each category. While FSVQA has much more answers in all categories, most striking example is in the yes/no category. VQA dataset essentially contains only two answers â€œyesâ€ and â€œnoâ€ for yes/no questions (infrequent answers such as â€œnot sureâ€ were filtered out in the conversion process). In fact, answering with â€œyesâ€ alone for all questions achieved 70.97% accuracy for yes/no category in the original VQA dataset. On the contrary, FSVQA datasets contain approximately 49,000 times more answer and 240,000 times more answers for yes/no category in each version. It becomes clear again that FSVQA cannot be taken advantage of by manipulating a small set of frequent answers.

Dataset Model VQA Acc. FSVQA Acc. BLEU-1 BLEU-2 BLEU-3 BLEU-4 METEOR Cider

Image 9.72 1.35 15.4 2.6 0.8 0.2 0.101 0.412

Image 14.41 0.87 26.3 8.7 4.6 3.2 0.094 0.601
references: Results for all metrics are shown in Table 5. Note that evaluation is performed on the results for validation split, since ground truths for test split are not publicly available. While each metric is concerned with slightly different aspect of the answers, results shows that they generally tend to agree with each other. Figure 3 shows examples of generated full-sentence answers for each model, along with the ground truth answer from the original VQA dataset.
